query: What did Barry Hughes think of the law as it presently stands when talking about reasonable punishment?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the law should reflect contemporary society and the law is evolutionary in nature, and should be changed to reflect the way in which people behave within society. In respect of children in particular, he pointed out that section 58 of the Children Act 2004 did make it a defence for a person accused of assaulting a child to argue that it was a case where they were acting only so as to impose reasonable punishment upon the child. But the more general criminal legislation, such as the Offences Against the Person Act, did provide specifically for adults and children alike not to be subject to physical assault.

Barry Hughes explained that there was a spectrum of offending. In England and Wales, the limit for having micrograms of alcohol in your breath is 35 µg in 100 ml of breath. Across the border in Scotland, it drops to 22 µg. Therefore, it would be more likely that the police would give this more consideration for referral to the CPS than beforehand, but it didn't necessarily mean they would refer it, because it would depend on the facts of each individual case. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, the approach would be along the lines of working with Kwame and his colleagues to make sure that the guidance that they issue nationally suits both England and

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the guidance when discussing the divergence between English and Welsh law?
summary: Dawn Bowden AM asked about the guidance on the divergence of criminal law and whether that needed amending to reflect it. Barry Hughes answered that they would need to update the guidance, and it went back to the application of the evidential stage, before the public interest stage.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the need for the CPS in England to be aware of the changes?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that it would not necessarily be helpful to see the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before they make their final decision. What they would envisage was that they would simply want to take the present public interest factors, which were set out, in my view, very clearly in the code for Crown prosecutors, and they would provide a degree of detail around those that relates more specifically to the issues that they were discussing here. And they would need to work that up as they went along.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the criminal law in Wales and England diverging in this particular instance?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the issue of whether something was punishment or not was going to disappear, providing that it was clear that contact with a child had happened. The change in the law here would afford children a degree of protection that they don't presently have, but which they do have when they attain the age of 16. However, it would not alter the basic responsibility of the prosecution, which was to establish its case beyond a reasonable doubt.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about what might be done to prevent cases even coming as far as arrest?
summary: From the perspective of the CPS, they were not sure how intervention might work better earlier on, even at the point of the knock at the door. Unlike in many other jurisdictions, they had no power whatsoever to direct the police, so if the police decided not to investigate, they could not do anything about it.

query: Summarize the discussion about the financial implications of the legislation.
summary: Suzy Davies AM asked about the practical and possibly financial implications for the workforce in this. Barry Hughes answered that there would be minor financial consequences for them and no significant financial consequences in the period between now and the Bill becoming law other than the time of themselves in discussing this today. They would keep a clear track on those cases that were referred to the CPS from the police and would have a very frank discussion about how they were doing with it all.

According to Barry Hughes, there was a long list of matters that they took into account. Some of them were fairly obvious, such as previous convictions. If someone's got previous convictions for doing something wrong, it was more likely they were going to be prosecuted the next time. But there was no part of the law that said that prosecution would always follow. So, when they applied the public interest test, the essence of it was about proportionality, and trying to come up with an approach that was proportionate to the offending. It was not determinative, nor was it determinative in cases where

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the work that was being done to explore this as an option?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, this was primarily a matter for the police, because there were a great many offences or reports of crime that did not reach the CPS because they were dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. There was quite a range, and life would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposal with more clarity about what each one of them involved.

Barry Hughes thought that raising awareness was important, and he was pleased to see that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation, which was now going through, reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales, and the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something which was potentially divisive, and

query: Summarize the discussion about unintended consequences.
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the risk of malicious reporting against parents involved in private family law cases. Barry Hughes answered that it was not something that would cause concern, simply because they already had a well-developed approach to dealing with the way in which they evaluated the evidence from parties who may well have a particular position that they wanted to reinforce, sometimes through exaggeration of basic facts and sometimes through fabrication. Moreover, the numbers of cases would be tiny, and dwarfed by the number of cases where they had to deal with the fallout between a relationship breakdown between partners—whether they be living within the same house or living in different houses. And, in his experience, the police were much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago, in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target.

query: Summarize the discussion about the potential barriers to implementing this proposed law.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there is a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecute 5 per cent of those in any given year. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions is, for him, not a reason not to signify that certain behaviour is or is not acceptable. The criminal law provides a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand.

query: Summarize the discussion about the new computers and parallelization

query: Summarize the discussion about the results of the experiments
summary: PhD A informed the team that he had been working on taking other submissions and performing improvements over their system. He found that the baseline itself improved by twenty-two percent by just giving the baseline. He also found that he needed to retune the time constants of the on-line normalization.

query: What did PhD D think about spectral addition?
summary: PhD D informed the team that spectral subtraction had finally been shown to improve on the sixty-four hertz cut-off. However, the well-matched condition was still slightly worse for well-matched. PhD D thought that the main mismatch was coming from the amount of noise and silence frames and all those present in the database.

query: What did PhD A think about combining noise and signal?
summary: PhD A thought that combining the Wiener filtering with signal subspace was a worthy idea. However, the professor pointed out that the advantage of combining two things was mainly coming from the noise, and it worked very poorly with the poor SNR conditions, and in colored noise.

query: Summarize the discussion about the new parameter to the traditional parameter
summary: PhD A explained that the team had been experimenting with adding an additional speech silence bit to the cepstrum and training the HMM on that. The team was also trying to find another feature for discriminate between voice sound and unvoice sound.

query: Summarize the discussion about the belief net.
summary: The belief-net was going to focus on building the influence links. The professor thought that it would be important to know which sets of things were relevant to which decisions and which kinds of belief nodes were needed in order to compute the belief nets. The belief nets would have to be propagated every single time it was updated or only when they needed to.

query: What did the professor think about ontology?
summary: The professor thought that the ontology was important because it was important to know what the object was selling or servicing. The ontology could also be used as an intermediate node for decision nodes. The professor also thought that accessibility and accessibility were important because if it was closed one probably won't enter, but if it is accessible to a tourist ever the likelihood of that person actually wanting to enter is higher.

query: What did the professor think about the structure of the model?
summary: The professor suggested that the model should be structured as a vector of several possible things, like Gothic churches versus Baroque townhouses versus a landmark at the same time as doing these things. The model could also be divided into subgroups, which could be computed by someone else.

query: What did the professor think about the decision to go to the castle?
summary: The professor thought that the Go-there decision would have a node from the discourse, and the endpoint would be fed by separate ones. The professor also thought that there should be a link between the endpoint and the user, but this was not feasible at the moment.

query: What did the professor think about the semantics?
summary: The professor thought that the semantics of the discourse would be of values that went into the various discourse-based decision nodes. He thought that it was not completely impossible, but it was probably beyond what the belief net could learn. He also thought it would be important not to have loops.

query: Summarize the discussion about decision nodes.
summary: The team discussed the basic problem of a belief-net and how to deal with a lot of different nodes all contributing to one node. The professor suggested that they could specify the conditional property of this given all the inputs, which was a first-order consideration. The team then discussed how to specify a valid probability distribution for each of the nodes, which would be a weighted average of the probabilities of each node given its parents.

query: Summarize the discussion about the training data

summary: According to Dafydd Evans, there are opportunities to join up employers and schools and education facilities a lot more than they do at the moment. The aim is an excellent one, but they've lost their way in terms of what they do present at the end of the day, and having more input from employers would be a great help.

Dafydd Evans thought that there were a number of priorities. It was a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a C grade in the core subjects. But that ate into the time that they had to teach young people. The Welsh baccalaureate, where it worked really well, did help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it was not for everyone, because some people had to do the other things. So, the priorities needed to be reviewed, to look at how they could make skilled and employable people

query: What did Nick Brazil think about the different levels of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Nick Brazil, at level 1 and level 2, it's not what they would call a crowd puller in colleges, but at level 3 it's more, especially for A-levels, because it can help them get into university. At level 4, for the more able and talented, four A-Levels is better.

Kay Martin thought that universities in the main did not believe the value of the Welsh baccalaureate, especially the experience they had with some of their learners to go to Russell Group universities. However, it was mixed, and it did depend on the admissions tutors and the areas that they were going into in universities. In some areas, and certainly the local universities around here—University of South Wales, Cardiff Metropolitan University—value it in a great number of subjects, particularly in sport, when our students went to Cardiff Met, and business studies when our learners went to USW. Then they do accept it. But some of the universities are not valuing the Welsh

query: What did Julie Morgan think of the bac as comparable to other qualifications?
summary: Julie Morgan thought that the baccalaureate was trying to be all things to all men. At one end of the spectrum it was a rigorous qualification that stood up to a Russell university's expectations, and on the other hand, it was supposed to develop softer skills and employment skills for people going into work from a vocational area. Therefore, Julie Morgan thought it was comparable as long as it was right for the learner's future. But if a learner wanted to go into a particular sector and the Welsh bac was not accepted, then it was not comparable.

query: What did Dr Rachel
summary: Dr Rachel Bowen thought it was perfectly possible for learners to reach FE college having attained the Welsh baccalaureate under the process that Dr Rachel Bowen had described, and without necessarily having gone through the holistic inquiry-based independent skills that they would want to see. The chances were that they had lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification.

query: Summarize the discussion about universal adoption.
summary: Suzy Davies thought that universal adoption was a bad idea at this moment in time because it reduced the amount of competition and advantage that certain institutions had. However, Kay Martin insisted that it was absolutely not used as a recruitment tool, because most of them, as you see, valued the Welsh baccalaureate in many cases. So, they wouldn't deliberately tell people, "Come on in and you won't have to do it".

query: Summarize the discussion about the more able and talented vocational learners, but also talented academic learners.
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, it was not a case of squeezing things out. It was part of what the college's curriculum offered—there was no doubt about that—and then people made a choice according to what they needed to do to actually progress to what their need to do in their future. There was a big range, and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. So, the Welsh baccalaureate starts to do some of those things at different levels.

query: Did anybody come to you and say, "Well, actually, I've really come here because I don't have to do the Welsh bac"?
summary: According to Nick Brazil, in terms of their offer, they offer a range in the curriculum. There are some places in, I would think, some sixth forms now, where certain qualifications may not be offered now because of the need to pick up an extra—Welsh baccalaureate—which can limit the choice of opportunities as well. So, what parents and learners are looking for is for the range of options. Education is about offering the range and offering it correctly.

query: Summarize the discussion about improving the status and perception
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that there were certainly instances of young people coming in with quite a negative attitude, originally, to the Welsh baccalaureate and taking it on board. But where they were delivering it well, well contextualised, they had really enjoyed the experience, and very much valued the experience. However, it was very difficult for them, as institutions, to change. Dr Rachel Bowen thought that it did make it into quite an intensive selling process for colleges when they had got to overcome that negative perception. As people had said already, it is possible to talk parents and learners round, but then that's time spent having to do that selling job when they should be talking about other things.

query: Summarize the discussion about universal adoption of A-Levels.
summary: Kay Martin thought that they were all heading for universal adoption, but because the Welsh baccalaureate had changed into something that wasn't 100 per cent what they thought it should be, they had stopped the universal adoption. They were trying to do what's in the best interests of the learner, but they were not sure at the moment. They needed to spend less time in checking what they had done on assessment and more time in the doing, and the experiential learning that they needed to do, rather than it being too much of a paper exercise.

query: Summarize the discussion about the process of developing the curriculum.
summary: According to Kirsty, there was a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity as possible. There were 24 focus groups that were arranged for children and young people. In October, there would be a number of workshops lasting three days at a time where those practitioners would continue that process of feedback with curriculum and assessment group and all those people involved. In terms of some of the things that people were asking us to look again at, some of that was around some the language used. So, they would be bringing it down again to the 'what matters' statements within that, again, providing greater certainty and greater clarity about our expectations at a national level.

query: Summarize the discussion about the religious education and relationships and sexuality education.
summary: According to Kirsty, the 'what matters' were the articulation of the big ideas. They were always intended to represent, as a whole, the learning that every learner should get. There was a need for learners, as they saw it, to be prepared to be part of a diverse and multicultural society. And there were many responses that were concerned about and emphasised the need to respect parents' views.

query: Summarize the discussion about potential unintended consequences.
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, the expectation is that they will publish a final version of the curriculum in January 2020, so schools will then have the opportunity to be really engaging in it. There were some issues raised about potential challenges with staff in talking about issues that they perhaps personally did not agree with with regard to this curriculum. With regard to guaranteed access to a full curriculum, there were strong views that, again, it should be parents, and parents alone, that made decisions about whether their children should have access to an entire curriculum rather than schools or the state setting those rules.

According to Kirsty, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and would have a bigger impact on children who were in danger of being left behind, were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. First of all, there would be a statutory framework to ensure that progression was the same wherever you were in Wales. Secondly, excellent teaching. Thirdly, strong leadership of our schools that ensured that there was no segregation, that had high expectation of all

query: What kind of lessons were being learned from the introduction of
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that it was always useful to reflect on how other systems had undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that had arisen. One of the lessons learned from Scotland was that they spent too much time on curriculum content rather than assessment. What they learnt was to get a smaller group to develop those materials and look to engage through cluster groups. They had pioneers who worked with clusters to test the development of that concept before they were looking for schools to go away and develop a larger amount of content.

query: Summarize the discussion about professional development preparation.
summary: According to Kirsty, it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. The four regional consortia were working together to provide consistency for classroom teachers and teaching assistants, and then the next stage of that development was for subject specifics. The money was being made available to each and every school and had empowered headteachers to really think, 'What are the professional needs of my school and the practitioners in my school?' Because some schools had been part of the pioneer process from the very beginning and therefore were further along that development chain. They were looking at developing potentially a stronger set of support, again on a national basis, for those who were newly qualified, beginning their teaching career, because they just simply didn't have a structure that allowed them to do that.

query: Summarize the discussion about how they were going to deal with the issue of teachers who are not trained in the new curriculum.
summary: According to Kirsty, they would continue to have a system where teachers trained in Wales will teach in England and teachers who have worked in England will come across the border, as well as teachers from other parts of the world coming to teach in Wales schools. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model. Each school that participates in the innovation schools programme gets £30,000. And they don't have a roll-call against all schools, but they require them, or request of them that they keep us informed of the networks.

query: Summarize the discussion about the assessment of pupils for their own progression and the evaluation of how a school does at certain points in its life cycle.
summary: According to Kirsty, the primary purpose for assessment was for that professional to be able to know how to move that child's educational journey on, and the purpose for categorisation was not to make a judgment on a school in the sense of a league table; it was a triage process, categorisation.

query: Summarize the discussion about the early steps of the teaching standards and the leadership standards and how well a school was performing against KPIs on those measures.
summary: According to Kirsty, the first part of the accountability regime would be the professionalism of individual members of staff. Then, the schools would be publishing self-evaluations annually, and the outcome of that would be a school development plan. The measures would still consider reflection on progress of children, but it would also have reviews of mental health, well-being, how it approaches that and things that it wanted to do. And the schools' ability—whether they do that well or whether they don't do it well—would be judged by Estyn.

query: Summarize the discussion about the single continuum of learning with regard to the Welsh language.
summary: Kirsty Williams thought it was really important that whatever resources they had to support the Welsh dimension were really, really, broad and not confined to specific areas. The continuum for language would have to be contextualised depending on the setting where a child was being taught. For example, children learning Welsh in a Welsh-medium school, their progressional on that point would be more speedy and quicker, and by the end of primary school they would be in a very different position than a child that was learning English in an English-language school.

Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked about the guarantee that all children and young people, where appropriate, would take part in physical activity under the new curriculum for Wales. Kirsty Williams AM assured her that they would be given that opportunity, because if they were not then that school would be in breach of the expectations that would be set out in statute. However, how would they monitor it?

query: Summarize the discussion about governance arrangements.
summary: According to Kirsty, statutory and non-statutory provision had been involved in the development of the curriculum because, of course, some of this was going to be delivered in the non-Statutory sector. But FE have been involved with this process from the very beginning. They had been setting a minimum standard around the purposes, around the cross-cutting themes and health and well-being, and then there would be an expectation that in conjunction with the child and the family an appropriate addition would be put in place to meet the needs of that child, recognising that they could have very different needs.

summary: Transcribers would not be able to distinguish between speakers' names in a noisy room. The team would have to figure out how to anonymize the data.

query: Summarize the discussion about the increase in the number of exclusions from school.

query: Summarize the difficulties that can arise between the money that is kept back by local authorities and the funding that goes directly to schools
summary: The WLGA was aware of the funding issues and the challenges of funding that face schools in general. However, it was difficult to know how headteachers and governing bodies would react. If they were under pressure financially or in terms of performance measures, they would react in a particular way. query: Summarize the discussion about the continuum of provision and support for learners.

query: What are the reasons for the delays that some children experience in accessing EOTAS?

query: Summarize the discussion about the curriculum as it stands and thinking about transferring to a new curriculum.

query: What did Nick Williams think about the lack of mental health support in mainstream schools?

At the minute, they didn't know what the overall impact was. They were looking at something very limited here, but they needed to look at it in the bigger picture of what's happening.

query: Summarize the discussion about the increase in younger children being excluded from school.
summary: According to Dr Ian Johnson, around 4 per cent of pupils are off-rolled between year 10 and 11, but they're also seeing a number between 1.5 and 2 per cent that are in any given year between year 8/year 9, year 9/year 10. It's concerning that they're seeing increases amongst younger children in particular, and they need to dig a bit deeper and understand the story behind that and whether there's a specific reason why schools were doing that, related to the accountability measures.

query: Summarize the discussion about adequate support
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked about the extent of adequate support provided to pupils who were at risk of becoming EOTAS. Dr Ian Johnson answered that they didn't have a simple answer to this one. However, there were a number of things that they need to do: they needed to recognise the impact of adverse childhood experiences; they needed train teachers so that they had an understanding response and were much more confident in that; they need listen to the voices of young people themselves. They also needed to look at the assets that young people had as well, which they could work with.

query: Summarize the discussion about the impact of individual tuition on learners
summary: Dawn Bowden AM asked about whether there was any impact on learners where there were actually delays in accessing EOTAS, again in terms of mental health conditions, if there was a delay in getting them to the appropriate provision. Dr Ian Johnson answered that they didn't have actual evidence to show the impact on pupils, but what they did know and something that was of huge concern was that there was no central data on how many young people were home schooled. Also, it was a concern, if children were very anxious in the school environment and in the classroom, if they knew they could get out of the classroom and get into a safe space, they would do that. So, there were definitely children who were labelled 'naughty', and they also played up to that as well.

query: Summarize the discussion about EOTAS provision.
summary: According to Dr Ian Johnson, it was important for teachers to be equipped with the training and to understand the link between inequality and all the things that come under that term, and challenging behaviour, and if teachers were aware of that, and trained properly to deal with that, the risk of exclusion would ultimately lessen. In terms of the whole-school approach and how it worked within the new curriculum, this was a vital point for the years to come. It meant foregrounding and having that in the heart of the school ethos, and ensuring everybody's well-being was important, and an important outcome of the work.

The team would use a project method consisting of three different design stages, functional design, conceptual design and detailed design. The first stage would search for the user requirements and make a specific specification of that. The second stage would be the technical functional design and how exactly the remote control would work in the technical sense. The last stage was the working design, which would be designed for the vision of the product.

query: Summarize the presentation on the project.
summary: Project Manager introduced that the SMARTboard would have a selling price of 25 Euros and a profit of 50 million Euros. The product would be sold internationally and the production cost should not be more than 12 Euro fifty.

query: Summarize Industrial Designer's presentation on remote control interoperability.
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that one remote control should control one or more pieces of equipment, and there should be some interoperabi interoperability between them. User Interface suggested that the remote should work on different TVs or even different devices.

query: What did User Interface think of the infrared function when discussing the technical function of the new remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer proposed that the remote control should be able to change the state of the TV by pressing the button. However, User Interface pointed out that it would be quite disturbing when users always had to point directly to the TV, so infrared should be restricted to that.

query: Summarize the discussion about user interface.
summary: User Interface suggested that the buttons for volume or whatever could be felt without looking at the buttons, and that the digits could be visible in the dark.

query: What did Industrial Designer and User Interface think about the cost of the new remote control when discussing the details of the project?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the cost price of the remote control was very low, so it was not going to be a high high-end product. User Interface thought that Bluetooth might be a problem because it was use a lot of time. However, Industrial Designer pointed out that cell phones had integrated Bluetooth also and it seemed to work quite okay, so technically it would be possible.
